Award.AwardTitle: Targeting Protein Function in Vivo using Small Interfering Proteins (SIPs)
Award.AbstractNarration: The ability to interfere with gene function is a common technique used to infer the role of genes in animals and plants. However, current technologies for disrupting gene function suffer from several limitations. For example, gene knockouts completely eliminate production of the protein coded by the gene. Consequently, it is difficult to eliminate a single function of multi subunit, multifunctional proteins or to target modified forms of a protein. Cellular processes are often mediated by chemical modifications to proteins, such as addition of a phosphate moiety. In this project, the investigators will evaluate the use of Small Interfering Proteins (SIPs) to specifically interfere with protein function, or parts thereof, in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. SIPs are small proteins that have been engineered to bind to specific domains of the targeted protein with high specificity and affinity. When SIPs bind to specific regions of target proteins, they should disrupt protein function. The investigators will express synthetic genes encoding SIPs targeting test proteins to evaluate the ability and use of SIPs to selectively target protein function in whole organism. If successful, SIPs will provide a valuable set of tools to study the molecular mechanisms underlying cellular function. These tools are expected to greatly improve our understanding of the biology of development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins are comprised of various domains that have different roles within a cell, some for interacting with other proteins, some for interacting with DNA and other cellular components.  Though some domains have known functions, others that are conserved in many animals have no known function. To address this, we attempted to design small interfering proteins (SIPs) that would bind to these domains and thereby interfere with protein functions.  The fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster is a well known genetic model organism, and we chose to express these SIPs in Drosophila embryos to determine if their binding to target proteins could alter the protein function, something that would cause a defect in development of these embryos.  We did obtain evidence that this technique could work, by injecting a known interacting protein to a conserved Drosophila protein.  However, we failed to obtain the desired result of expressing a SIP via an in vivo expression system and having that disrupt protein function. The main problems were generating soluble protein targets that could be used to select binding SIPs and the inability to identify SIPs with sufficient affinity to function in vivo.  This award provided training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students as well as for a beginning technician.  The graduate student gained much experience in protein engineering. The undergraduate participated in many further research projects, even in a study abroad program.  Without this research experience, it is unlikely that she would have had such opportunities. She plans to enter graduate school after her undergraduate is finished.   I should add that she is an Engineering major, a field noted for lack of women members.
